Pro Log: New green jersey for the Tour de France, Vuelta a Femenina route reveal and Strade Bianche horse update

Welcome back to Pro Log, our round-up of interesting news from the past week of professional cycling. This weekend marked the inevitable ‘Is Strade Bianche a Monument?’ discourse, as both Tom Pidcock (Ineos Grenadiers) and Demi Vollering (SD Worx) won in Siena.

Elsewhere, Paris-Nice is underway with Tim Merlier victorious in the opening stage bunch sprint as a rainy Tirreno-Adriatico kicked off with an individual time-trial today.

1. Strade Bianche horse update

Now this is something you don’t see every day!
A horse wanted to join in on the action today at #StradeBianche ?
Luckily it didn’t stirrup much trouble for @demivollering

Watch the race highlights over on GCN+ ? https://t.co/8FSJcLL3Gx pic.twitter.com/eNejiP3i5B

— GCN Racing (@GcnRacing) March 4, 2023

Demi Vollering let out an almighty scream while riding at Strade Bianche. A horse had bolted onto the course, presumably startled by the fanfare and helicopter. Concern arose as it continued to gallop along the roads of Tuscany – both for rider safety and the horse’s wellbeing.

The horse then fell over going into a bend and wasn’t shown again. After the race, the owner took to Facebook to let everyone know the horse, who’s called Zlatana, is doing okay but will be on antibiotics for a week.

Vollering went on to win Strade Bianche in a two-up sprint against teammate Lotte Kopecky, which led to some interesting post-race pictures when no one could figure out if that was actually the plan. But soon hugs ensued, and Vollering posted a photo of the pair on Instagram, writing that she was thankful for their ‘nice battle’ to the finish and that it was a moment to treasure forever.

2. AG2R-Citroën don denim bib shorts

They didn’t get a result at Strade Bianche, but at least they did it with some style. Depending on who you ask. After being granted permission by the UCI, AG2R-Citroën wore special stretch denim bib shorts designed by technical partner Rosti to the race, where Clément Venturini was their highest-placed rider in 44th place.

Results powered by FirstCycling.com

Results powered by FirstCycling.com

AG2R-Citroën are known for their trademark divisive brown bib shorts, now a staple in races, so perhaps it was inevitable they would venture further into the world of marmite clothing design. Denim has kind of graced the peloton previously in the 1990s, when the Carrera team famously wore lycra designed in the style of denim.

3. New green points jersey at the Tour de France

Regarding fashion, Santini is changing the green colour of the jerseys worn at Paris-Nice, the Critérium du Dauphine and the Tour de France.

Usually a distinctive colour befitting the points classification leader, the jersey is now a dark green with a mint collar and bands on the sleeves. A watered-down Team Europcar colour, if you will. Personally, I’m not a fan of the change. A bright green jersey is easily identifiable in the peloton and unmistaken for a team jersey.

Alas, Soudal-QuickStep’s Tim Merlier currently leads the points classification at Paris-Nice, but due to also leading the general classification and therefore wearing the yellow jersey, Bora-Hansgrohe’s Sam Bennett is keeping it warm for the time being.

4. Inaugural La Vuelta Femenina route revealed

Kicking off on the 1st May 2023, La Vuelta Femenina will depart from Torrevieja. This will be its inaugural edition in a new format of a seven-day stage race in May having previously been known as Ceratizit Challenge by La Vuelta and held in September, with Annemiek van Vleuten (Movistar) the 2021 and 2022 winner over five stages.

La Vuelta Femenina boasts a varied route comprised of one team time-trial, three flat stages, one medium-mountain stage and two mountain stages, finishing on the famed Lagos de Covadonga.

  • Dates: 1st – 7th May 2023.
  • Stage 1: Torrevieja – Torrevieja, 14.5km. (ITT)
  • Stage 2: Orihuela – Pilar de la Horadada, 105.1km.
  • Stage 3: Elche de la Sierra – La Roda, 148.2km.
  • Stage 4: Cuenca – Guadalajara, 133.1km.
  • Stage 5: La Cabrera – Mirador de Peñas Llanas, Riaza, 129.2km.
  • Stage 6: Castro-Urdiales – Laredo, 106.7km.
  • Stage 7: Pola de Siero – Lagos de Covadonga, 93.5km.
  • Total: 703.3km

5. Caleb Ewan asks for clarity following second place in Flanders

I kinda think I won. Thoughts? pic.twitter.com/Oaa2sK9obJ

— Caleb Ewan (@CalebEwan) March 5, 2023

Lightening never strikes twice. Unless you’re Caleb Ewan. Just days after being pipped by Tim Merlier by the thinnest of margins at the UAE Tour, Lotto-Dstny’s Ewan unfortunately encountered a similar fate at GP Jean-Pierre Monseré. The one-day race was a lengthy 200km in the saddle for the peloton, culminating in a sprint finish.

Despite initially labelling Ewan the winner, the decision was reversed to give it to Gerben Thijssen (Intermarché-Circus-Wanty). Thijssen called it an honour to win ‘ahead of a champion like Ewan’ for his first victory of the season and handed his bidon to a young child after the finish. Naturally, it produced many a tweet analysing pixels on a screen and questions about giving two riders the victory. It will be interesting to see if that ever happens, imagine the scenes on the Champs-Élysées.
